What is compelling about any of those characters?
Well, let's just take a look at Master Chief in Halo 4. In the story, Chief is portrayed at the start as a stalwart soldier who wants to save Cortana. However, as the story goes along, more and more layers of Chief's humanity are revealed showcasing a man who has to contend with an emotional loss rather than a obstacle. The narrative showcases that his determination to save Cortana is actually a denial of reality in the fact that Cortana is going to die. It's important to note that both he and Cortana's character arcs are directly tied with one another in this story as it explores the nature of humanity with two characters who embody ways in which they are not human. Cortana not only questions what she herself is, but places that question forward to Chief to consider as well. The fact that his character arc places him in that mode of existential questionings showcases just how much deeper Chris Schlerf's fantastic script is willing to delve into the real meat of these characters, and gives his character so much more hope as a person as he begins to reflect on his humanity through loss. That's one very brief description of one character.
We could talk about Blazkowicz's abstract American ideology in how the dichotomy of good and evil are eventually vindicated through that lens, how Booker's obsession with solving problems through denial and violence lead him to self-destruction, Jackie's obsession with Jenny in the Darkness games acting as both a redeemer for the character as well as a center of damnation, Elizabeth's justifications for her actions actively leading her to be worse than her father and her redemption from that providing the spine of her narrative.
Let's take a look at Artyom in the Metro games (for protagonists with "audience choice" attached to them). His personal struggle doesn't come from a desire for personal change, but rather his want to see his community and humanity thrive and the difficult decisions concerning what is the best course of action moving forward.
